macro_markets.query: What are the most important macroeconomic and stock market news and developments from the past 24 hours? Include major index movements, Fed/central bank news, and significant company earnings or announcements.

items.title: Major US Stock Indexes Rally on Tech Strength and Economic Data
items.summary: The S&P 500 rose 0.3% to 6,944.47, the Dow gained 0.6% to 49,442.44, and the Nasdaq climbed 0.2% to 23,530.02 on Thursday. The rally was driven by strong earnings from Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and positive economic reports, though cyclical sectors like industrials and financials faced headwinds.

items.title: Oil Prices Ease on Iran Tensions, Supporting Market Recovery
items.summary: Oil prices declined sharply on hopes for calming tensions in Iran, helping to stabilize the broader market after a two-day losing streak. The S&P 500 edged back toward the all-time high it set on Monday.

items.title: Labor Market Shows Mixed Signals with Job Openings Decline
items.summary: JOLTS data revealed a sharp drop in job openings, signaling cooling labor demand, while ADP reported a modest rebound in private-sector hiring and the ISM Services PMI surprised to the upside, reinforcing views of a slowing yet resilient economy.

items.title: Tech Stocks Lead Gains; Banks Decline on Economic Concerns
items.summary: Nvidia and Alphabet rallied, with Alphabet gaining 2.5%, while JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America fell more than 2% amid broader pullback in financial stocks. Energy stocks showed mixed performance with refiners advancing on Venezuelan crude flows.

crypto_news.query: What are the most significant cryptocurrency and blockchain news from the past 24 hours? Include major price movements, regulatory news, and notable project developments.

items.title: US Spot Bitcoin ETFs Record $1.7 Billion Inflows in 3 Days as BTC Surpasses $97K
items.summary: US spot Bitcoin ETFs saw $1.7 billion in inflows over the last three days, reversing prior outflows and driving Bitcoin's price above $97,000 from recent $88,000 lows. This surge aligns with ongoing US crypto regulatory bill discussions despite Senate delays.[1]

items.title: Senate Banking Committee Postpones Crypto Market Structure Hearing
items.summary: The Senate Banking Committee delayed a hearing on crypto market structure legislation amid industry pushback, contributing to slides in major cryptocurrencies. The Senate Agricultural Committee also postponed its bill release and hearing.[3][6]

items.title: iShares Issues 880,000 Additional Bitcoin ETP Securities on London Stock Exchange
items.summary: iShares Digital Assets AG issued 880,000 Bitcoin ETP securities priced at $9.66 each, set for trading on the London Stock Exchange's Main Market starting January 16, 2026. Each security represents a decreasing cryptoasset entitlement of 0.0001 Bitcoin.[4]

items.title: Bitcoin Fails to Hold Above $97K as Crypto Markets Flatten
items.summary: Bitcoin cooled from its rally above $97,000 with crypto markets mostly flat despite sustained ETF inflows, as analysts describe it as a transitional phase.[5]

items.title: Democrats Criticize SEC's Dismissal of Major Crypto Cases Including Binance
items.summary: A Democratic letter highlights the SEC's dismissal of key crypto cases like Binance without justification, raising concerns over investor risks and ties to figures like Trump and CZ.[2]

items.title: SEC Chair Predicts US Financial Markets Fully On-Chain in 2 Years
items.summary: SEC Chair Paul Atkins forecasted that US financial markets will move fully on-chain within a couple of years, as stated in a December Fox Business interview.[7]

ai_news.query: What are the most important artificial intelligence and machine learning news and developments from the past 24 hours? Include new model releases, company announcements, research breakthroughs, and industry trends.

items.title: Meta Acquires Manus for $2B at CES 2026
items.summary: Meta announced a $2 billion acquisition of Manus at CES 2026, highlighting the shift toward physical AI and robotics. The event also featured discussions on AI infrastructure constraints and the rise of inference-focused LPUs.

items.title: Groq Secures $20B Licensing Deal with Nvidia for LPUs
items.summary: Groq revealed a $20 billion licensing deal with Nvidia at CES 2026 to advance LPUs, promising 5-20x faster inference and separating training from inference workloads for better AI performance.

items.title: World Economic Forum Launches Lumina AI Platform for Industry
items.summary: The WEF added 23 new sites to its Global Lighthouse Network and launched Lumina, an AI-powered platform for industrial transformation, emphasizing AI with IoT and sustainability for 16% better performance.

items.title: Income Lab Releases AI Scribe for Retirement Planning
items.summary: Income Lab launched AI Scribe, which transcribes Zoom client meetings to automatically generate or update retirement plans, freeing advisors from manual data entry.

items.title: martini.ai Updates Credit Research Assistant with Financials Integration
items.summary: martini.ai enhanced its AI credit research assistant to analyze uploaded financial statements using knowledge graphs and graph attention networks for real-time insights on 3.5 million companies.

items.title: Brookings Report Warns of AI 'Brainrot' in Students
items.summary: A Brookings study highlights AI causing cognitive decline in students through over-reliance, leading to reduced critical thinking, reading skills, and idea originality, termed a 'great unwiring'.

gaming.query: What are the most notable video game and gaming industry news from the past 24 hours? Include game releases, announcements, esports, and industry developments.

items.title: Video Game Industry M&A Hits Record $161 Billion in 2025
items.summary: Mergers and acquisitions in the video game industry reached a record $161 billion, driven by deals like the Public Investment Fund's $55 billion acquisition of Electronic Arts, Netflix's likely purchase of Warner Bros., and Scopely's buyout of Niantic. Drake Star predicts continued activity in 2026 with private equity and potential IPOs like Discord.[1]

items.title: Meta Cuts Over 1,000 Jobs and Closes VR Game Studios
items.summary: Meta has laid off more than 1,000 employees as part of a major restructuring in its Reality Labs division, including the closure of VR game studios.[3]

items.title: Ubisoft Lays Off 55 Jobs at Massive Entertainment and Stockholm Studios
items.summary: Ubisoft announced 55 job cuts at Massive Entertainment and Ubisoft Stockholm, unrelated to performance, following voluntary redundancies and the closure of its unionized Halifax studio.[1][6]
items.source: Video Games Industry Memo / Game Developer

items.title: Game Developers Choice Awards 2026 Nominees Announced
items.summary: Nominees for the 2026 Game Developers Choice Awards have been revealed, with Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 leading the nominations.[7]

items.title: Edmonton Video Game Testers Ratify First Union Contract
items.summary: Video game testers in Edmonton have ratified their first collective agreement, including wage increases, leaves of absence, and health benefits.[9]

items.title: Cineverse and GameStop Partner to Promote 'Return to Silent Hill' Film
items.summary: Cineverse teamed up with GameStop for in-store promotions and giveaways to hype the January 23 theatrical release of the 'Silent Hill 2' adaptation film.[4]

items.title: Discord Potential IPO Signals Gaming Industry Growth
items.summary: Analysts view Discord's possible IPO as a major validation for the gaming sector's venture appeal and potential for large-scale public offerings.[5]

items.title: AGDQ 2026 Raises $2.44 Million for Prevent Cancer Foundation
items.summary: Awesome Games Done Quick event from January 6-10 raised $2.44 million for charity through speedrunning feats like blindfolded Majora's Mask and Guitar Hero Resident Evil.[1]

tech_news.query: What are the most important technology news and developments from the past 24 hours? Include major product launches, company news, and significant tech industry developments. Exclude AI-specific news.

items.title: TSMC Boosts 2026 Capital Spending to $56 Billion Amid Strong AI Demand
items.summary: TSMC announced it will increase capital spending by at least 25% to as much as $56 billion in 2026 and forecast faster-than-expected revenue growth, reviving confidence in AI demand and lifting technology stocks and Europe's Stoxx 600 to a record.

items.title: US Imposes 25% Tariff on Nvidia's H200 AI Chips Exported to China
items.summary: The Trump administration formalized a 25% tariff on Nvidia's H200 semiconductors headed to China, balancing competition for US chip industry jobs while allowing sales to approved commercial customers vetted by the Department of Commerce.

items.title: Nvidia Showcases Rubin Architecture and Autonomous Vehicle Model at CES 2026
items.summary: At CES 2026, Nvidia revealed its Rubin architecture for powerful chips and an AI model for autonomous vehicles, highlighting major hardware advancements alongside other robotics developments.

items.title: Boston Dynamics and Google Partner on Atlas Humanoid Robots at CES 2026
items.summary: CES 2026 featured a partnership between Boston Dynamics and Google on Atlas humanoid robots, marking a significant push in robotics technology.

items.title: Lego Makes CES Debut with Launch of Smart Bricks
items.summary: Lego appeared at CES 2026 for the first time, launching Smart Bricks as part of innovative tech product introductions.
